benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/catalog/xml - Retrieve the full catalog as XML

covered: Valid Request: Core successful retrieval scenarios for latest catalog and for combinations of requestedDate and accountId (TC01-TC04) are present.
Query Parameters: Positive and negative parameter handling is tested (valid requestedDate/accountId, invalid formats, unsupported extra parameters) (TC02, TC03, TC04, TC07, TC08, TC09).
Empty Response / No Data: Scenarios for no catalog or empty catalog structure are included (TC05, TC15).

Error Handling: Multiple error paths are covered including not found for date/account (TC05, TC06), invalid input (TC07, TC08, TC13), auth failures (TC10, TC11), service/dependency failure (TC12), timeout (TC22), and previous regression for malformed XML (TC19).
Response Format/Content-Type: Tests assert Content-Type text/xml and valid/well-formed XML and schema/backwards compatibility (TC01, TC02, TC19, TC20).
Performance/Scalability: High-level performance and load scenarios are specified (large catalog, peak load, concurrency, SLAs) (TC17, TC18, TC21).
Security/Robustness: Injection/malicious input handling and ensuring no unintended commands executed is covered (TC13).
gaps: Pagination: No tests cover pagination or chunked/partial retrieval behavior for very large datasets (Standard GET guideline: Pagination).
Caching Behavior / HTTP headers: No scenarios assert caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified) or behavior when If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since are used.
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for rate limiting, throttling, or behavior under excessive request frequency (Standard GET guideline).
Accept header negotiation and content-negotiation: No tests for Accept header handling (e.g., client requests application/xml vs text/xml) or response when unsupported Accept is provided.

Exact status-code expectations for some error cases: Story specifies >=400 for errors; tests allow 400 or 404 in places — gaps in asserting canonical status code semantics for particular error conditions (e.g., when to use 400 vs 404 vs 422).
Headers and metadata validation: Beyond Content-Type, response headers (Content-Length, charset, security headers) are not validated.
Input boundary/length validation specifics: TC16 mentions max lengths but does not enumerate exact limits/behavior; missing explicit boundary tests and malformed-but-still-valid-length edge cases.
Detailed schema validation: While well-formedness and backward compatibility are covered, there is no explicit test asserting full XML schema compliance against a definitive XSD.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: create scenarios for paginated responses or confirm API does not paginate and document behavior; include very large dataset retrieval verifying either pagination or streaming behavior.
Add caching tests: verify ETag and Cache-Control headers, and tests for conditional GETs using If-None-Match / If-Modified-Since to confirm 304 responses when appropriate.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate bursts of requests to verify 429 responses or throttling behavior and ensure graceful handling.
Add Accept-header and content-negotiation tests: verify behavior when clients request different media types and when unsupported types are requested.
Tighten status-code expectations: convert ambiguous “400 or 404” assertions into explicit expected codes per business rules, and add tests for 422 vs 400 where relevant.
Add header-level assertions: check Content-Length, charset, and relevant security headers (e.g., X-Content-Type-Options) as applicable.
Add explicit XSD/schema validation tests: validate the XML body against the official catalog XSD to ensure full schema compliance, not just well-formedness.
Clarify and test boundary conditions for parameter lengths and exact validation rules (TC16), including min/max lengths and invalid-but-edge-case inputs.
